let's talk first of all about what cloud is doing to software procurement at a generic level so you're all AWS users we
believe you're provisioning and putting up systems on AWS already and clearly what AWS has done is we've taken a lot
of the friction out of the procurement of compute Network and Storage
and up to the database layer such that you can essentially identify and provision very very quickly the reality
is however a lot of projects require a collection of software assets that have
to be deployed on that resource and as an indication of just how much software gets deployed on top of compute Network
and resource the way you should think about this is that worldwide in terms of computing
compute Network and storage is about 150 billion dollar industry the software that gets deployed on that
compute resource is about 300 billion so really the software ratio to the compute
capacity model is about a six to one ratio so everybody in this room is probably picking multiple products and
historically you know software's been around for a long time and in a physical on-premise model you have procurement
cycles that involve a lot of Contracting a lot of negotiation supplying of the
software it's not a quick fast model so there's a mismatch between the frictionless model that we've put in
place for compute Network and storage and then the provision of the software that you may have
if you think of the server infrastructure that you replace when you move to AWS the world's got about 35 to
40 million Intel servers if you think of that as the dominant architecture out there those servers are slowly moving
into the cloud and you actually all own software assets that you've licensed for an on-premise machine
and so as you think about moving a workload into AWS you're likely having a
library of software for which you have licenses you have rights to use and some of those licenses will give you the
rights to move them into a cloud environment some licenses are written not to give you that freedom to move into a virtualized or a cloud
environment it really does depend on the vendor but what's happening over time is that as you move more and more of your
workloads into the infrastructure available in AWS you're really refreshing your software library and you
refresh your software Library the opportunity that we've been thinking about since 2010 and we switched on
Marketplace was how do we change the way that you then procure and consume the library of software that you're
typically using and at the velocity of workloads that are moving to Cloud if you listen to a
guy called math Eastwood from IDC who studies a shift to Cloud you know Matt
would say that at the current rate and velocity by about 2018 50 of all workloads will have moved into a cloud
infrastructure which really means that your software library that you may be contracting on a three or a five-year
license model is really shifting over to what we would call a consumption based model
and so you should think that in your software Library asset you have a library of software you have on-premise
Computing you have cloud computing and as you move your workload in you're going to be retiring in all the license model and your thought process is going
to be what's my new license model for cloud so the way we thought forward on this
when we built our Marketplace and we switched Marketplace on interestingly three years ago this month so the
marketplace library of software which really is a catalog from which you can search find and deploy that Library
actually switched on three years ago with about 150 titles Kevin yeah one of the reasons we're doing an update here
is we're adding and expanding that Library every day so as of Monday we are

Amazon thinking on shopping experience and we take that shop and fail as a

out a lot of software what we also do is that the marketplace team is actually part of the AWS platform organization so

buying one five 10 or 15 products you have an open running subscription established with the marketplace engine
that is tagged into the billing engine and now we've paired your experience right into the bill
the other thing we're doing is scaling out and so if you work for a global Corporation we were both in Frankfurt
